Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 08:42AM Shannon-GA wrote: I also wanted to add that even though I knew the warnings of a "slight increased risk of breast cancer", I honestly never gave it much thought since I didn't have any other risk factors.  I didn't think much about it until after I found the lump and starting researching it on the internet and found that some studies showed that years of use put you at a higher risk.
Posts.Title: EXTENDED ORAL CONTRACEPTIVE USE & BREAST CANCER...RELATED? AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 07:59AM Shannon-GA wrote: Same here, my doctor was all over it as well.  This has been on my mind ever since I found my lump and I immediately stopped taking them.  I'm still waiting and hoping mine is benign, but I definitely feel that my 16 years of oral contraceptive use has something to do with my "heterogeneously dense breast tissue" and lump.  I'm sure I will never know for sure.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 06:49AM Shannon-GA wrote: OhanaDreams - Are you able to find a specialist through your insurance network that you can bypass your gp and make an appt with the specialist yourself?  If you have to get a referral from your gp first, it's possible that there are steps that he has to take before he can refer you out, although it seems odd that you had an ultrasound first and now he's having you do a mammogram.  I feel for you, the whole process does take a long time and it can be very frustrating, especially your situation.  Keep on it and don't be afraid that you think you are being overly anxious, it's your life and not your doctor's.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 08:53AM Shannon-GA wrote: Hi ihatescreennames (love the name by the way) I'm 37 years old, had the scare and my results were benign.  If you click on my name, you'll see my previous posts, so I'll try to keep this short and sweet.  Although, you can see from my previous posts that I tend to be wordy. :) I felt a lump in the upper right axillary area at the end of June 2009, went to see my PCP in early July.  She sent me for a diagnostic mammo and the radiologist did an ultrasound at the same time.  Neither one showed anything other than asymmetric dense breast tissue and I was told to come back in 6 months.  I decided to see a surgeon for further evaluation since there was a specific palpable lump about the size of a peanut.  He suspected it may be a swollen lymph node and wanted to wait 4 weeks to see if changed at all since there are many reasons a lymph node may be swollen.  When it didn't change in the 4 weeks, he decided to take it out for testing.  It turned out not to be a swollen lymph node, but an ectopic piece of breast tissue that was benign.  I won't tell you not to worry until there is something to worry about, because I know that you will worry anyway!  This site is a wonderful place to get information and support during this time.  Good luck to you and please keep us posted on here.  I will be keeping you in my thoughts for benign results! Take care.
Posts.Title: Anyone who had a similar situation can you share your story? ihatescreennames whatisthis

Posts.Title: Anyone who had a similar situation can you share your story? ihatescreennames whatisthis

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 07:55AM Shannon-GA wrote: Have you ever heard of just simply "normal, benign breast tissue" coming back from a biopsy? Brady - to answer this question....yes.  I had a lump in my outer upper portion of my right breast, the doctor thought it may be a swollen lymph node, had an excision and the path report indicated "normal benign breast tissue."  It is possible.  But if you are not comfortable with it, then it looks like you are doing what you can to get further testing.  Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Freaking out again - finally read mammo / us report brady0819 flash

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 06:50PM Shannon-GA wrote: Hi Robolegs, I'm new here too.  I found a lump that didn't show up on the mammo or ultrasound and was told to come back in 6 months for a recheck.  For me personally, I can't wait that long, especially since I can feel a lump.  I have an appt to see a surgeon next week.  I would rather him tell me it's nothing than to wait 6 months and find out it's something.  Peace of mind is golden and if you have any concern at all, 6 months is awful long time to wait if you are worried. Also, from what my mammo report indicates, BiRad 4 is "Suspicious Abnormality". Good luck in whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 05:51AM Shannon-GA wrote: Good luck AmyMarie, I'm keeping you in my thoughts today!  I too don't understand the comments about women who are seeking out their own cancer.  I would think that being proactive is a good thing, the earlier found the better the chances of beating it, isn't that what we all are being told?  The medical industry can't drill into our heads the necessity of yearly screenings in order to detect it early and then gawk at those that want more of an answer than what they are given, especially given the statistics of false negatives.  As many have mentioned on here, each person knows their own body and if something doesn't feel right, then seek answers.

Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Shannon-GA wrote: Hi Ladies, I've been browsing this website for the last couple of weeks after I found a lump in the axillary node area (it's a little larger than a pea and rounded) and thickening in the outer breast area and around this lump, which my primary doctor felt as well and referred me for a diagnostic mammogram.  I had to wait 2 weeks, but I just got back from having the mammo and also an ultrasound done, and I'm a little confused and concerned about the radiologist's reading of the tests.  I first had the mammo, which the mammo tech could feel the lump, so she did some extra pics of that area.  Then she said the radiologist wanted to do an ultrasound now as well.  The u/s tech could also feel the lump, but it didn't show up on the image.  The u/s tech said she could only see breast tissue and couldn't see the lump.  After all was said and done, the radiologist came in and asked me if I could feel the lump.  I told him yes, and he asked if it was mobile or fixed.  I told him it seemed fairly mobile to me, it does move when you push on it.  He never felt for the lump.  He told me that it is breast tissue that has "veered" off into that area.  Has anyone else ever heard of this?  I asked him if breast tissue could be firm and round, and he never really answered that, but said he couldn't see anything other than breast tissue, although he did mention that it looks different than my left breast tissue.  He said for me to come back in 6 months for a recheck, unless something changes before then.  I'm 37 with no family history of breast cancer. Don't get me wrong, I'm happy that they didn't find anything, but on the other hand I'm worried that the lump can be felt and nothing showing up.  It's not a cyst, swollen node, nothing?  It just seems odd to me.  I've sent a message to my primary doctor to see what she thinks of his opinion.  I'm just curious if anyone else has heard of this.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 02:02PM Shannon-GA wrote: Also, is it normal that nothing was mentioned on the mammogram of my left breast?  Am I just to assume that everything was ok with it?  I would guess so, but you would think that it would indicate that the left breast was negative.
Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 03:42PM Shannon-GA wrote: Thank you to everyone that have responded, I really appreciate you taking the time. Update is that I spoke with my sister in law, who is a surgical tech. She said that I needed to go see a breast surgeon, even if just for the doctor to look at it and say "yep, it's breast tissue." She said that if I can feel a lump, then it's best to have it examined further and to definitely not wait 6 months.  Before I had a chance to hear back from my primary doctor, I went ahead and made an appt. to see a breast specialist.  I called my primary doctor's office and told them that I wasn't waiting 6 months and that I had made the appt. to see the surgeon.  I got a call back from my primary doctor and she agreed that I shouldn't wait and that she was sending a referral to the surgeon.  She said it's better to be safe and have it be nothing than to wait and have it be something.  I feel better now.  Thanks again ladies and I'll keep you updated on how things go.
Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 01:59PM - edited Jul 20, 2009 02:58PM by Shannon-GA Hi AusMum, congrats on your outcome! Update:  I received a copy of my mammogram/ultrasound report from my doctor:  Diagnostic Bilateral Mammogram: Routine views as well as exaggerated craniocaudal views of the breasts are obtained.  This is the patient's baseline examination.  There is no family history of breast cancer.  A marker is placed at the site of the palpable abnormality in the axillary right breast.  The breast contains heterogeneously dense fibroglandular tissue thereby limiting sensitivity of the study.  There is a vague focus of glandular density in the axillary region of the right breast corresponding to the palpable abnormality and additional spot compression MLO projection was also obtained demonstrating the glandular density.  No nodularity was noted and additional evaluation with ultrasound was performed. Right Breast Ultrasound: Transverse and longitudinal images of the right axillary region in the area of the palpable abnormality was performed.  There is no underlying cystic or solid nodules. Impression: Probable asymmetric glandular density in the axillary right breast corresponding to the palpable abnormality.  As there are no prior mammograms available for comparison, a 6 month followup of the right breast is recommended.  ACR Category 3. This study was R2 read (computer-aided detection device). Information regarding mammography: Dense breast tissue, such as adenosis, fibrocystic changes, etc., may obscure an underlying problem/neoplasm.  Approximately 10% of cancers are not detected with mammography.  A negative mammography report should not delay biopsy if a clinically suspicious mass is present. Results: BIRAD: 3 - Probably Benign Finding(s)  Follow Up: 6 months. So, from what I read, it basically states what the radiologist told me, which is he thinks it is breast tissue, which would be great if I couldn't feel a specific round hard lump that does not feel anything like the surrounding tissue and still has me worried.  I had to look up "heterogeneously dense fibroglandular tissue" to get an idea of what he was referring to, and I guess it's just really dense breast tissue.  In my searching on the internet, I came across sites that had research that seems to indicate that women with denser breast tissue are at a higher risk of developing breast cancer.  Has anyone else seen this or heard anything about this?  I should probably stop looking up things on the internet, it has me paranoid now, but at the same time it's been very eye opening....it's made me realize how much I didn't know about breast cancer, or the breasts in general.
Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 04:29PM Shannon-GA wrote: Hi everyone - I had posted this long post about my appt today with the surgeon, but figured it sounded too harsh against my doctor, which wasn't my intent.  I fully trust this doctor and I am comfortable with his decision.  Short story of my appt today, he believes the lump is a swollen lymph node and wants to watch it at this point.  I have an appt in 4 weeks for another evaluation and possible excision of the lymph node if it is still swollen or has gotten any bigger.  I asked why it would be swollen and he said it's hard to tell at this point since nothing obvious could explain it, I haven't been sick and no cuts or infection recently.  I believe that if he felt that it was something more serious that he would be doing something sooner.  So, the waiting continues....
Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 05:11PM Shannon-GA wrote: Hi Joan - I sent you an email. Also, I wanted to mention, and this is really just for information in case anyone new is going through this as well, but my doctor said that the reason the lump wasn't showing up on the u/s was because the node is located just beside my muscle and when I lay back, the node is covered by the muscle and breast tissue, which would also explain why it's hard to feel it when I lay down.  He asked me if I was laying down when the u/s was done and I was.  I told him that I had explained to the u/s tech when she was doing the test that it was hard to feel when I was laying back, but I guess she didn't think it would make a difference.  The doctor said she should have had me sit up.  This is why he has not recommended an MRI, he felt that it most likely wouldn't show up on the MRI as well. He also felt that a needle biopsy wouldn't get enough of a sample, and may actually miss something, and I would end up doing an excision anyway, so he didn't want me to have to go through 2 procedures.  Same reasoning for not doing the core needle biopsy, but with that he also was concerned about the fact that they basically "shoot" the needle into the lump and since the node is so close to the muscle, ribs and lungs, he wasn't comfortable with doing that procedure.  This is why he wants to go straight to the excision if it comes to that.  Hopefully it won't come to that and maybe it will just go away.
Posts.Title: Lump is actually breast tissue? Shannon-GA Shannon-GA

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 09:01PM Shannon-GA wrote: Oh Trabby, I'm so sorry.  Wait until at least Monday???  Hopefully it will come in sooner.  Every place is different, but it's a shame they couldn't have had a radiologist on site at the time to give you some indication of what was being seen, if anything.  When I had my ultrasound done, it was the same thing, they just focused on the palpable lump and area of density, not the whole breast.  I'm not sure if that's the normal process, but that's how mine went as well.  Maybe you can call in a couple of days and see if they have the report done yet?
